introduction.p:
Suppose that we have a network that is partitioned into (potential) communities. The type of a vertex is the community C that it belongs to. The modularity of a network G is given by
Q = \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i} \sum_{j} \left( A_{ij} - \frac{k_i k_j}{2m} \right) \delta (C^{(i)}, C^{(j)}) = \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{C} \sum_{i \in C} \sum_{j \in C} \left( A_{ij} - \frac{k_i k_j}{2m} \right)
where
A is the adjacency matrix
m is the number of edges in the network
k_i is the degree of vertex i
C^{(i)} is the type of vertex i
\delta(x,y) = \left\{ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & \mbox{if } x=y \\ 0 & \mbox{otherwise} \end{array} \right.
The modularity satisfies -1 < Q < 1. A modularity score of Q > 0.3 indicates significant community structure.

statement.p:
Use this link to a Google Sheet to explore the ways to partition graphs on four vertices. You may add self-loops, but such a loop corresponds to A_{ii}=2 (so that the degrees are correct).
Can you find a graph and a partition with modularity greater than 1/2? If not, why not?
Can you find a graph and a partition with modularity less than -1/2? If not, why not?

Modularity measures the extent to which edges are internal to communities, compared with spanning different communities. We will explain why this is the case. Basically, we are comparing the actual structure of the network with the expected structure of a network where we randomize the edges (but preserve the vertex degrees).
Explain why the following expression counts the total number of edges
\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i} \sum_{j} A_{ij}
Now explain why the following expression counts the total number of edges that are internal to one of the designated communities.
\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i} \sum_{j} A_{ij} \, \delta (C^{(i)}, C^{(j)})
which can also be written as
\frac{1}{2} \sum_{C} \sum_{i \in C} \sum_{j \in C} A_{ij}.

Now we will randomly rewire the network. We keep the ends of the edges, so that the vertex degrees do not change (see the figure to the right). We erase the edges themselves, which gives us a configuration like the one pictured to the right. Next, we randomly add edges between pairs of vertices, until all edges have been redrawn. Loops are allowed, as are multiple edges between pairs of vertices.

Note that the degree of vertex i will still be k_i when this process is done.
Pick the start of one edge at vertex i. What is the probability that this rewired edge connects to vertex j?
So how many rewired edges from vertex i do we expect to connect to vertex j? (Assume that the network is so big that the chance that two ends at i try to connect to the same end at j is irrelevant.)
Now argue that the expected number of rewired edges that are internal to the specified communities is
\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i} \sum_{j} \frac{k_i k_j}{2m} \, \delta (C^{(i)}, C^{(j)})
which can also be written as
\frac{1}{2} \sum_{C} \sum_{i \in C} \sum_{j \in C} \frac{k_i k_j}{2m}.
Here, the \frac{1}{2} takes care of the double counting since our sum looks at the pair i,j twice.
We subtract the expression in question 4(c) from the expression in question 3(b). We then divide by the total number of edges m (a normalizing factor) to get the modularity
Q = \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i} \sum_{j} \left( A_{ij} - \frac{k_i k_j}{2m} \right)\, \delta (C^{(i)}, C^{(j)}),
which can also be written as
Q = \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{C} \sum_{i \in C} \sum_{j \in C} \left( A_{ij} - \frac{k_i k_j}{2m} \right).

exercise.title: Modularity as a Random Walk Measure

idx.h: Modularity as a Random Walk Measure

statement.p:
We can rewrite our modularity equation as
Q \, = \, \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{C} \sum_{i,j \in C} \left( A_{ij} - \frac{k_i k_j}{2m} \right) \,= \, \sum_{C} \sum_{i,j \in C} \left( \frac{A_{ij}}{k_i} \frac{k_i}{2m} - \frac{k_i }{2m} \frac{k_j }{2m} \right)

ol.li:
Confirm that this expression is equivalent to
Q \, = \, \sum_{C} \sum_{i,j \in C} \left( P^{\top}_{ij}\pi_i - \pi_i \pi_j \right)
where P = D^{-1} A^ is the random walk transition matrix and \pi is its stationary distribution, where \pi_i=k_i/2m.

li.p:
Consider a random walk whose distribution has converged to the stationary distribution \pi.
Explain why \sum_{i,j \in C} P^{\top}_{ij}\pi_i is the probability that we are in C at time t and t+1.
Explain why \sum_{i,j \in C} \pi_i \pi_j is the probability that we are in C at time t and t+T for very large T.

ol.li: Modularity is the difference of the two quantities in part (b). Using this random walk interpretation, why is this difference a measure of community structure?
